title: Combining Excel and Delimited Data
text:
library (readxl)
library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.2
✔ ggplot2   4.0.0     ✔ tibble    3.3.0
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.1.0     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


Read excel file for white wine data

whitewine_tbl <- read_excel("../white-wine.xlsx",
                             sheet = excel_sheets("../white-wine.xlsx")[1]
 )
whitewine_tbl

# A tibble: 4,898 × 12
   `fixed acidity` `volatile acidity` `citric acid` `residual sugar` chlorides
             <dbl>              <dbl>         <dbl>            <dbl>     <dbl>
 1               7               0.27          0.36             20.7     0.045
 2              63               0.3           0.34              1.6     0.049
 3              81               0.28          0.4               6.9     0.05 
 4              72               0.23          0.32              8.5     0.058
 5              72               0.23          0.32              8.5     0.058
 6              81               0.28          0.4               6.9     0.05 
 7              62               0.32          0.16              7       0.045
 8               7               0.27          0.36             20.7     0.045
 9              63               0.3           0.34              1.6     0.049
10              81               0.22          0.43              1.5     0.044
# ℹ 4,888 more rows
# ℹ 7 more variables: `free sulfur dioxide` <dbl>,
#   `total sulfur dioxide` <dbl>, density <dbl>, pH <dbl>, sulphates <dbl>,
#   alcohol <dbl>, quality <dbl>


Reading variable names and renaming variables

whitewine_name <- read_excel("../white-wine.xlsx",
                            #col_names = FALSE,
                              sheet = excel_sheets("../white-wine.xlsx")[2]
)
colnames(whitewine_tbl) <- whitewine_name[[1]]

Adding wine type column

whitewine_tbl |>
  mutate(type = "white")

# A tibble: 4,898 × 13
   fixed_acidity volatile_acidity citric_acid residual_sugar chlorides
           <dbl>            <dbl>       <dbl>          <dbl>     <dbl>
 1             7             0.27        0.36           20.7     0.045
 2            63             0.3         0.34            1.6     0.049
 3            81             0.28        0.4             6.9     0.05 
 4            72             0.23        0.32            8.5     0.058
 5            72             0.23        0.32            8.5     0.058
 6            81             0.28        0.4             6.9     0.05 
 7            62             0.32        0.16            7       0.045
 8             7             0.27        0.36           20.7     0.045
 9            63             0.3         0.34            1.6     0.049
10            81             0.22        0.43            1.5     0.044
# ℹ 4,888 more rows
# ℹ 8 more variables: free_sulfur_dioxide <dbl>, total_sulfur_dioxide <dbl>,
#   density <dbl>, pH <dbl>, sulphates <dbl>, alcohol <dbl>, quality <dbl>,
#   type <chr>


reading red wine data

red_wine_tbl <- read_delim("https://www4.stat.ncsu.edu/~online/datasets/red-wine.csv",
                             delim = ";"
)

Rows: 1599 Columns: 12
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ";"
dbl (12): fixed acidity, volatile acidity, citric acid, residual sugar, chlo...

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

colnames(red_wine_tbl) <- whitewine_name[[1]]

red_wine_tbl |>
  mutate(type = "red")

# A tibble: 1,599 × 13
   fixed_acidity volatile_acidity citric_acid residual_sugar chlorides
           <dbl>            <dbl>       <dbl>          <dbl>     <dbl>
 1           7.4             0.7         0               1.9     0.076
 2           7.8             0.88        0               2.6     0.098
 3           7.8             0.76        0.04            2.3     0.092
 4          11.2             0.28        0.56            1.9     0.075
 5           7.4             0.7         0               1.9     0.076
 6           7.4             0.66        0               1.8     0.075
 7           7.9             0.6         0.06            1.6     0.069
 8           7.3             0.65        0               1.2     0.065
 9           7.8             0.58        0.02            2       0.073
10           7.5             0.5         0.36            6.1     0.071
# ℹ 1,589 more rows
# ℹ 8 more variables: free_sulfur_dioxide <dbl>, total_sulfur_dioxide <dbl>,
#   density <dbl>, pH <dbl>, sulphates <dbl>, alcohol <dbl>, quality <dbl>,
#   type <chr>


Combining two wine data sets in one data set

wine_tbl <- bind_rows(whitewine_tbl, red_wine_tbl)

Calculating mean and standard deviation of alcohol variable for each quality variable

wine_tbl |>
  filter(quality > 6.5 & alcohol < 132 ) |>
  arrange(desc(quality)) |>
  group_by(quality) |>
  select(contains("acid"), alcohol, quality)|>
  mutate (mean_alcohol = mean(alcohol), sd_alcohol= sd(alcohol))

# A tibble: 1,206 × 7
# Groups:   quality [3]
   fixed_acidity volatile_acidity citric_acid alcohol quality mean_alcohol
           <dbl>            <dbl>       <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl>        <dbl>
 1            91             0.27        0.45     104       9        122. 
 2            66             0.36        0.29     124       9        122. 
 3            74             0.24        0.36     125       9        122. 
 4            69             0.36        0.34     127       9        122. 
 5            71             0.26        0.49     129       9        122. 
 6            62             0.66        0.48     128       8         94.1
 7            62             0.66        0.48     128       8         94.1
 8            68             0.26        0.42     105       8         94.1
 9            67             0.23        0.31     107       8         94.1
10            67             0.23        0.31     107       8         94.1
# ℹ 1,196 more rows
# ℹ 1 more variable: sd_alcohol <dbl>

title: Conceptual Questions
text:
If your working directory is myfolder/homework/, what relative path would you specify to get the file located at myfolder/MyData.csv?


../MyData.csv


What are the major benefits of using R projects?


R projects organizes everything like settings, packages, environment so that we can easily share the project between multiple Operating Systems


What is git and what is github?


Git is a version control system that allows taking snapshots of files/projects and github is an online platform to store and mange such files/projects using git.


What are the two main differences between a tibble and a data.frame?


Data frame is a data structure in base R which store 2 dimensional data or tabular data.Tibble is a data structure in tidyverse package which internally uses data frame. Data frame always prints the whole table by default but tibble provides meaningful information of the table and print only 10 rows.

5.Rewrite the following nested function call using BaseR’s chaining operator:
arrange(filter(select(as_tibble(iris), starts_with(“Petal”), Species), Petal.Length < 1.55), Species)

as_tibble(iris) |> select (starts_with (“Petal”), Species) filter(petal.length < 1.55) |> arrange (Species)

title: Homework 4
text: Multilple pages for reading data from files and combining data

title: Reading Delimited Data
text:
Loading library tidyverse

library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.2
✔ ggplot2   4.0.0     ✔ tibble    3.3.0
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.1.0     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


Reading glass data

glass_tbl <- read_csv("https://www4.stat.ncsu.edu/online/datasets/glass.data",
                      col_names = c("Id","RI","Na","Mg","Al","Si","K","Ca","Ba","Fe", "Type_of_glass")
)

Rows: 214 Columns: 11
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
dbl (11): Id, RI, Na, Mg, Al, Si, K, Ca, Ba, Fe, Type_of_glass

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

glass_tbl

# A tibble: 214 × 11
      Id    RI    Na    Mg    Al    Si     K    Ca    Ba    Fe Type_of_glass
   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>         <dbl>
 1     1  1.52  13.6  4.49  1.1   71.8  0.06  8.75     0  0                1
 2     2  1.52  13.9  3.6   1.36  72.7  0.48  7.83     0  0                1
 3     3  1.52  13.5  3.55  1.54  73.0  0.39  7.78     0  0                1
 4     4  1.52  13.2  3.69  1.29  72.6  0.57  8.22     0  0                1
 5     5  1.52  13.3  3.62  1.24  73.1  0.55  8.07     0  0                1
 6     6  1.52  12.8  3.61  1.62  73.0  0.64  8.07     0  0.26             1
 7     7  1.52  13.3  3.6   1.14  73.1  0.58  8.17     0  0                1
 8     8  1.52  13.2  3.61  1.05  73.2  0.57  8.24     0  0                1
 9     9  1.52  14.0  3.58  1.37  72.1  0.56  8.3      0  0                1
10    10  1.52  13    3.6   1.36  73.0  0.57  8.4      0  0.11             1
# ℹ 204 more rows



glass_tbl |>
  mutate(Type_of_glass = ifelse (Type_of_glass==1, "building_windows_float_processed",
                       ifelse (Type_of_glass==2, "building_windows_non_float_processed",
                       ifelse (Type_of_glass==3, "vehicle_windows_float_processed",
                       ifelse (Type_of_glass==4, "vehicle_windows_non_float_processed",
                       ifelse (Type_of_glass==5, "containers",
                       ifelse (Type_of_glass==6, "tableware",
                       ifelse (Type_of_glass==7, "headlamps",
                                                 "error")))))))
       ) |>
  filter(Fe < 0.2 & Type_of_glass %in% c("tableware","headlamps"))

# A tibble: 38 × 11
      Id    RI    Na    Mg    Al    Si     K    Ca    Ba    Fe Type_of_glass
   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <chr>        
 1   177  1.52  14    2.39  1.56  72.4  0     9.57  0        0 tableware    
 2   178  1.52  13.8  2.41  1.19  72.8  0     9.77  0        0 tableware    
 3   179  1.52  14.5  2.24  1.62  72.4  0     9.26  0        0 tableware    
 4   180  1.52  14.1  2.19  1.66  72.7  0     9.32  0        0 tableware    
 5   181  1.51  14.4  1.74  1.54  74.6  0     7.59  0        0 tableware    
 6   182  1.52  15.0  0.78  1.74  72.5  0     9.95  0        0 tableware    
 7   183  1.52  14.2  0     2.09  72.7  0    10.9   0        0 tableware    
 8   184  1.52  14.6  0     0.56  73.5  0    11.2   0        0 tableware    
 9   185  1.51  17.4  0     0.34  75.4  0     6.65  0        0 tableware    
10   186  1.51  13.7  3.2   1.81  72.8  1.76  5.43  1.19     0 headlamps    
# ℹ 28 more rows


Yeast data
Reading Yeast.data

yeast_tbl <- read_table("https://www4.stat.ncsu.edu/online/datasets/yeast.data",
                        col_names = c("seq_name","mcg","gvh","alm","mit",
                                      "erl","pox","vac","nuc","class")
)


── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
cols(
  seq_name = col_character(),
  mcg = col_double(),
  gvh = col_double(),
  alm = col_double(),
  mit = col_double(),
  erl = col_double(),
  pox = col_double(),
  vac = col_double(),
  nuc = col_double(),
  class = col_character()
)

yeast_tbl

# A tibble: 1,484 × 10
   seq_name     mcg   gvh   alm   mit   erl   pox   vac   nuc class
   <chr>      <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <chr>
 1 ADT1_YEAST  0.58  0.61  0.47  0.13   0.5   0    0.48  0.22 MIT  
 2 ADT2_YEAST  0.43  0.67  0.48  0.27   0.5   0    0.53  0.22 MIT  
 3 ADT3_YEAST  0.64  0.62  0.49  0.15   0.5   0    0.53  0.22 MIT  
 4 AAR2_YEAST  0.58  0.44  0.57  0.13   0.5   0    0.54  0.22 NUC  
 5 AATM_YEAST  0.42  0.44  0.48  0.54   0.5   0    0.48  0.22 MIT  
 6 AATC_YEAST  0.51  0.4   0.56  0.17   0.5   0.5  0.49  0.22 CYT  
 7 ABC1_YEAST  0.5   0.54  0.48  0.65   0.5   0    0.53  0.22 MIT  
 8 BAF1_YEAST  0.48  0.45  0.59  0.2    0.5   0    0.58  0.34 NUC  
 9 ABF2_YEAST  0.55  0.5   0.66  0.36   0.5   0    0.49  0.22 MIT  
10 ABP1_YEAST  0.4   0.39  0.6   0.15   0.5   0    0.58  0.3  CYT  
# ℹ 1,474 more rows


Removing columns seq_name and nuc and calculating mean and median grouping by class

yeast_tbl |>
  select(-seq_name, -nuc) |>
  arrange(class) |>
  mutate (across(where(is.numeric), list(mean = mean, median = median),
                 .names = "{.col}_{.fn}")) |>
  group_by(class) |>
  view()
